IDENTIFYING ORGANIZATIONAL GAPS 
----
Agenda
----
9:00 | Settle in
9:15 | Identifying and filling gaps
10:25 | Break
10:40 | Partnerships
11:35 | Finding key partners
11:55 - 12:00 | Wrap up
----

9:00 | Settle in
Tea/coffee
Answer entrepreneur questions related to their prototypes, the pitch or anything else.

9:15 | Begin the session
Good morning everyone! How are you doing today? 
Today will be the first step in a series of leadership sessions that will help you strengthen your business operations. Before bringing in new team members, it’s essential to assess your organizational gaps and explore different ways to fill those gaps. 


Identify the skills and knowledge gaps in your business.

Learn how to fill gaps by building strong partnerships.

Create a plan to build partnerships based on your business needs.



1 minute: Objectives

Identify the skills and knowledge gaps in your business.
Learn how to fill gaps by building strong partnerships.
Create a plan to build partnerships based on your business needs.

YOUR BUSINESS MODEL:
REVENUE STREAMS
COST STRUCTURE
CUSTOMER SEGMENT
CHANNELS
CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIPS
VALUE PROPOSITION
KEY RESOURCES
KEY ACTIVITIES
KEY PARTNERS
*https://strategyzer.uservoice.com/knowledgebase/topics/113454-using-our-tools-canvases-methods
2 minutes: Lecture

The trainer should recap where we are on the BMC. 
We have already talked a lot about the right side of the BMC. We have been developing our products/services to fit the needs of our different customer segments. We have also looked at how those products and services will bring in profits through our revenue and cost structures. Now we are going to look at the left side of our BMC which is the internal part of our business. 

KEY ACTIVITIES
Marketing
Logistics
Product Development
Operations
Strategy

5 minutes: Brainstorm

The first step to identify your business gaps, is to understand all the activities and resources you need to efficiently and effectively deliver your product/service to your customer.
Ask: What are all the key activities (or actions) that we need to do in order to deliver our products/services to our customers? – Write all answers on the whiteboard. Try to get entrepreneurs to be specific.
Potential answers:
Marketing
Researching customers needs
Creating marketing materials
Posting ads
Holding event
Logistics
Delivery
Storage
Transportation
Product development
App maintenance
Market research
Prototyping and testing
Operations
Production
Finance
HR
Strategy
Planning
Partnerships
Financing
Marketing
Etc…

If entrepreneurs are having a hard time thinking about key activities, consider going over the points shown in this Mckinsey model to help entrepreneurs brainstorm some other key activities and resources needed. The seven areas of organization are divided into the ‘soft’ and ‘hard’ areas. Strategy, structure and systems are hard elements that are much easier to identify and manage when compared to soft elements. On the other hand, soft areas, although harder to manage, are the foundation of the organization and are more likely to create the sustained competitive advantage.
Strategy is a plan developed by a firm to achieve sustained competitive advantage and successfully compete in the market. Someone needs to be focusing on creating a well-aligned strategy that is clearly articulated, long-term, and helps to achieve competitive advantage.
Structure represents the way business divisions and units are organized and includes the information of who is accountable to whom. Someone needs to organize the company in terms of management and organizational structure and tasks.
Systems are the processes and procedures of the company, which reveal business’ daily activities and how decisions are made. What are the systems that are in place (or need to be created) that determine how business is done and it should be the main focus for managers during organizational change.
Skills are the abilities that firm’s employees perform very well. They also include capabilities and competences. During organizational change, the question often arises of what skills the company will really need to reinforce its new strategy or new structure. Each business will need specific skills. Tourism business needs someone knowledgeable about local historical sites and fun places to go. A consulting business needs employees with technical business knowledge. What specific skills do you need?
Staff element is concerned with what type and how many employees an organization will need and how they will be recruited, trained, motivated and rewarded. Someone needs to train and onboard staff!
Style represents the way the company is managed by top-level managers, how they interact, what actions do they take and their symbolic value. In other words, it is the management style of company’s leaders. Setting a company culture could be considered a key activity. How do you make sure that all areas of the business are abiding by your policies and living by the company culture?
Shared Values are at the core of McKinsey 7s model. They are the norms and standards that guide employee behavior and company actions and thus, are the foundation of every organization. 
You can also use a SWOT analysis to find gaps. 

Recap: Doing this can help you in a few ways including:
To help understand the gaps that may appear in the business
Identify which areas you should focus on to optimize or boost your business performance
Think about the results of future changes within your business



Given my key activities,
what are MY capabilities?

Key Activities – My Capabilities = Business Needs
What am I good at?
What are the roles and responsibilities I can take?

WHAT CAN I DO MYSELF?
5-10 minutes: Brainstorm

Next, we should take a look at all the things that we can do ourselves. 
Ask: Which of these things (on the board) can we do on our own? What processes could be optimized to improve efficiency? Think about if it was just 1 founder running this business. What can they realistically do?  
Circle each of the things on the board and identify if you can do them or not: 
Potential answers:
Marketing
Researching customers needs- I can do this, and should do it often.
Creating marketing materials- I can do this, but I am not good at it. 
Posting ads- I can do this.
Holding event- I can do this, but might need some help.
Logistics
Delivery- I don’t have the capacity to do this with the number of orders I am expecting.
Storage- I have space for a small amount of storage. I can do this now, but need to find another solution as I grow..
Transportation- I can’t do this. There is too much to deliver to and from cities. 
Product development
App maintenance- I can’t do this. 
Market research- I can do this.
Prototyping and testing- I can do this except for the technical parts (coding).
Operations
Production- I can do this, but will need help as I grow. 
Finance- I can do this now, but will need help as I grow.
HR- I can do this, and should be very involved. 
Strategy – As the founder, I should be heavily involved in the strategic parts of my business!
Planning
Partnerships
Financing
Marketing

Ask: When thinking about what you can do yourself, what are some things that you should keep in mind?
What you are good at. What skills are you lacking?
What you are excited and happy doing.
What you have time and energy to do.
What you (a founder) should be focusing your energy on, and what you can delegate to others. 
Your budget and ability to delegate things to others.
Etc…

Finally, once you have identified your key activities and what you are currently able to do, you are clearly able to see the gaps! Point out all the areas that aren’t circled on the whiteboard. We need to find a way to get those things done. 
5

WHAT’S NEXT?
Do it yourself!
Hire
Partner
3-5 minutes: Discussion

Ask: Once you identified the gaps, what are the three primary ways to fill them?
Do it yourself: We already talked about things that you can do yourself; however, if you want to grow your business and have it be successful, you need to enroll others to join your team and operations. 
Partner: Another thing you can do is partner with someone to help you do those things. You can outsource another person or company to help you to fill that gap. Maybe you aren’t good at marketing, you can use an advertising agency to help you fill that gap, for example. We will go more into this point today!
Hire: Another way is through hiring someone onto your team to fill the gap. We will go deep in this part in the next lead session!

45 minutes: Activity

After we explain the process of identifying gaps and the ways to fill those gaps, we will have an activity to apply it in the handouts folder. 
Each entrepreneur will work on identifying their gaps and setting a plan to fill those gaps. 
30 minutes: Individually work on the handout. The trainer will be around to help people fill out the document the right way. 
15 minutes: Group discussion and sharing. What are the biggest gaps entrepreneurs are facing? What are the major challenges entrepreneurs are facing to fill those gaps? Are there ways to work with each other to fill those gaps?

PARTNERSHIP
5 minutes: Discussion

We will now go deeper into strategic partnerships as one of the ways to fill organizational gaps. We will look at examples of different types of partnerships and the benefits that each one has. 
Ask: Before we give some examples, what do you think are the different types of partnerships you can have? Think of ways that you can work with other people to have mutually beneficial outcomes?
Potential answers:
Buyer-supplier partnerships can help you get better deals and manage your workflows better.
You can partner with companies and organizations that have similar missions to yours to spread awareness about your business or help each other get customers,
An investor is a partner! 
You can partner with influencers on social media,
Etc…


A partnership is an arrangement where 2 or more individuals or groups agree to cooperate to advance their mutual interests.
WHAT IS A PARTNERSHIP?
1 minute: Lecture

Basically, a partnership is an arrangement where 2 or more individuals or groups agree to cooperate to advance their mutual interests. The partners in a partnership may be individuals, businesses, interest-based organizations, schools, governments, or any combination of those things. We will now go over a few examples of common types of partnerships.


9

Joint Venture Partner
A joint venture occurs when two or more businesses join together to pursue a common project.
TYPES OF PARTNERSHIPS:
+
10 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Here you may join your company with another to create an entirely different entity, which may be more profitable for the both of you than if you were to operate separately.

Give a few examples or ask the class for examples of a joint venture (you don’t have to explain all of them below, just enough to get people understanding what it is):
Universal and Warner Bros. are entering a joint venture on sales, marketing and distribution of Blue Ray DVDs in North America. Separately, Universal will handle distribution for WB’s physical media in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Japan starting in Q3 of 2020 while WB will do the same for Universal’s physical media in the U.K., Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. Under the proposed structure, the studios will continue to operate their digital distribution businesses independently and retain content and consumer marketing for both physical and digital.
You can have another person join as a partner.  silent investor, they are not decision making people, they don’t have a certain role in the business. Vs of the general partner that has a certain role and they are decision making persons. Here is an example of a limited (silent) partner vs general (active) partner: 
Let’s say, “Shwan” runs a food café business and has “Majd” as his partner. In this business, Shwan is the general partner whereas Majd is a limited partner. “Majd” has given $1 million in the business as a capital investment. The money helps “Shwan”, pay for his staff expenses and purchase raw material. “Majd”, does not participate in running the business but receives monthly share out of the profits.
BMW Group and Toyota Motor Corporation (TMC) are pursuing their successful strategic long-term cooperation in the field of sustainable mobility today by signing binding agreements aimed at long-term collaboration between the two companies for the joint development of a fuel cell system, joint development of architecture and components for a sports vehicle, and joint research and development of lightweight technologies. These agreements follow a memorandum of understanding signed in June 2012.


Ask: Why would a business want to form a joint venture?
To combine resources. A bigger entity may have more clout in an industry or more resources to ensure the success of a venture. 
Joint ventures have shared investment, expenses, and profits (or losses). 
To combine expertise. In technical businesses, one company might have expertise in one part of a venture while the second company might have expertise in another part. For example, Company A might be good at creating software, while Company B has experience creating the hardware that's needed for a venture.
To save money. Two companies might consider a joint venture to save money on advertising, maybe at a trade show or in a trade publication.
To enter a foreign market. In this case, a foreign company forms a joint venture with a U.S. company that is in the market the foreign company wants to enter.
To manage rental property. A joint venture may form a partnership to own and rent properties together.

10

Strategic Alliance Partner

An agreement between two or more parties to pursue a set of agreed upon objectives needed while remaining independent organizations. 
TYPES OF PARTNERSHIP:
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

This means that you and a company that you have no direct competition with, industry wise, will partner together in ways that will benefit the both of you.

Give a few examples or ask the class for examples of a strategic alliance (you don’t have to explain all of them below, just enough to get people understanding what it is):
Local example: Mr. Erbil and Lala Candles joined together to create Mr. Erbil branded candles. They used Mr. Erbil’s luxury brand name and Lala candles high quality product to create something new that they can both benefit from. 
Spotify and Uber: Leaping forward to a very recent piece of news, Spotify and Uber have partnered to provide stereo control to Uber customers. Not every Spotify consumer uses Uber, nor does every Uber rider have a Spotify account. The strategic alliance allows each company to pursue prospects from the other’s existing customer base, all while continuing to promote both products. In both cases, it gives the company a leg up over its competition. Spotify is offering something with the Premium package that other streaming services do not yet have. And likewise, Uber can provide the riders with an opportunity to listen to their own playlists as opposed to other ride-share services that cannot match them yet.
You can partner with a manufacturer to produce a part of your business product that you yourself may not be able to manufacture. In return, you have a contract to pay for these parts that your partner has made you.
Starbucks has created several strategic alliances that you can see on the next slide. 
https://www.allbound.com/resource-center/successful-strategic-alliances-5-examples-of-companies-doing-it-right/


11

TYPES OF PARTNERSHIP:
Strategic alliance partnership example:


5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Starbucks has created several strategic alliances that have helped them increase sales and reduce costs related to production and distribution of their products. 
They partnered with Barnes and Nobles bookstores in 1993 to provide in-house coffee shops, benefiting both retailers.
In 1996, Starbucks partnered with PepsiCo to bottle, distribute, and sell the popular coffee-based drink (Frappuccino). In this situation they benefited off of PepsiCo’s highly efficient manufacturing and distribution channels. 
A Starbucks – United airlines alliance has resulted in their coffee being offered on flights with the Starbucks logo on the cups

Ask: Why would a business want to form a strategic alliance? 
Sharing resources and expertise. 
New-market penetration. In some cases, a strategic alliance gives access to new markets with a solution that wouldn’t have been possible for either company on their own. For instance, companies going global often work with a trusted local partner to get an advantage in an emerging market.
Expanded production. When it comes to manufacturing and distributing products, strategic alliances allow partners to increase their capabilities and scale quickly to meet demand.
Drive innovation. With the right alliance, partners can outpace the competition with new solutions that are a complete package for their customers. These alliances are creative and revolutionary and change the market landscape in a dramatic way.
Strategic alliances allow partners to scale quickly, build innovative solutions for their customers, enter new markets, and pool valuable expertise and resources. And, in a business environment that values speed and innovation, this is a game-changer.
https://www.workspan.com/blog/strategic-alliance-definition/



TYPES OF PARTNERSHIP:
Strategic alliance partnership example:


5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Asyad and be’ah Partnership – Oman
Asyad Group, Oman’s leading logistics provider, has formed a strategic alliance with be’ah, Oman’s waste management company, to deliver sustainable logistics solutions.
This partnership commitment to operational excellence, environmental stewardship, supporting and empowering small and medium enterprises (SMEs), and enhancement of in-country value (ICV) under the Oman Investment Authority (OIA) umbrella.
Be’ah brings expertise in waste management and environmental solutions, while Asyad contributes logistics infrastructure and supply chain capabilities.
The collaboration supports Oman Vision 2040, aiming to position the country as a global trade hub.

Ask: Why would a business want to form a strategic alliance? 
Sharing resources and expertise. 
New-market penetration. In some cases, a strategic alliance gives access to new markets with a solution that wouldn’t have been possible for either company on their own. For instance, companies going global often work with a trusted local partner to get an advantage in an emerging market.
Expanded production. When it comes to manufacturing and distributing products, strategic alliances allow partners to increase their capabilities and scale quickly to meet demand.
Drive innovation. With the right alliance, partners can outpace the competition with new solutions that are a complete package for their customers. These alliances are creative and revolutionary and change the market landscape in a dramatic way.
Strategic alliances allow partners to scale quickly, build innovative solutions for their customers, enter new markets, and pool valuable expertise and resources. And, in a business environment that values speed and innovation, this is a game-changer.
Source: https://asyad.om/who-we-are/media-center/news/2025/02/23/asyad-and-beah-partnership-to-deliver-sustainable-logistics-solutions-oman?_gl=1*eade9i*_gcl_au*MTg0MDU4MDM5OS4xNzQwOTkxOTM2 

Competition Partner
A group of competing companies come together to develop a solution for a problem that they all share, and none of them would gain a competitive advantage.
TYPES OF PARTNERSHIP:
10 minutes: Lecture + discussion

In these relationships, one or both partners views the other partner's success as something to thwart or outdo rather than a joint victory. Such a partnership will help spread the risk both companies may take. 

Give a few examples or ask the class for examples of a competition partner (you don’t have to explain all of them below, just enough to get people understanding what it is):
Pfizer + Merck: Another successful example of competitive collaboration is the powerful alliance between Pfizer and Merck (both in pharmaceuticals). These pharma companies entered a strategic partnership to bring new cancer treatments to the market as soon as possible. Although they are competitors, they invested together to save money and find solutions that they can both benefit from faster. 
Samsung and Sony formed an agreement in 2004 to share research and development costs in an effort to both design flat screen LED television. Again, they are both competitors who invested in something they can both benefit from. 
YouTube and Vimeo have a similar relationship. During an innovation panel at the 2019 ForbesWomen Summit, Vimeo CEO Anjali Sud shared that the video platform joined forces with YouTube, one of its main competitors by allowing creators to publish their videos to YouTube, as well as to other video platforms.
Google supported Mozilla (Firefox web-browser), a rival to Google Chrome, in order to limit the expanding influence of Microsoft Internet Explorer and Apple Safari.

Ask: Why would a business want to form a competition partnership?
Outcompete another competitor
It may also help when both partners are trying to do something new and share the risk of investment.
It could mean a confirmed supply stream. For example, there is a need for earth metals in mobile phones. So securing the supply of rare earth metals could be the reason for competitors to form a strategic partnership.

14

Buyer-supplier relationships refer to commercial transactions between organizations for the purchase and supply of goods or services.
Buyer-Supplier Partner
TYPES OF PARTNERSHIP
10 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Here you may join another company and agree to use each other as the go-to supplier/buyer for a product..

Give a few examples or ask the class for examples of a joint venture (you don’t have to explain all of them below, just enough to get people understanding what it is):
Intel and Lenovo: Lenovo uses Intel microprocessors in all of their computers. By doing this, they have been able to ensure consistent quality in their products, create a more efficient supply chain, and possibly have saved money through the negotiation process. 
Businesses in the bazar probably buy all their items from one place. They could be on an automatic schedule with their suppliers or they have built relationships and can easily order whenever they need. They don’t need to research many different suppliers every time they need new products. They know what they are getting each time from the same person/company. 

Ask: Why would a business want to form a buyer-supplier partnership? 
Cost saving
Time saving
It will make things faster and easier
You can get a better deal
You will have same suppliers that can lead to consistent quality
You can trust each other because of a long term relationship

15

HOW ARE PARTNERS PAID?
3-5 minutes: Discussion

Ask: How are partners paid?
Potential answer:
There is no specific way that a partner is supposed to get paid. It will all depend on your agreement. 
Some partners are owners, not employees, so they don't get a paycheck. Each partner receives a share of the profits and losses of the business each year. Payments are made based on the partnership agreement.
Partnerships use a partnership agreement to clarify the relationship between the partners, the roles and responsibilities of the partners, and their respective shares in the profits or losses of the partnership. 
There are some partnerships that are paid monthly or at the time that a product or service is delivered. Making the partnership might allow for a discount or reliability (consistent on time delivery without having to go through the process of ordering, for example).
Sometimes they don’t get paid. They just share in mutually beneficial activities.


16

WHAT PARTNERS SHOULD YOU LOOK FOR?
15 minutes: Activity

10 minutes: Activity
Based on the gaps we have identified and the different types of partnerships we have discussed, who should you partner with? Try to be specific and think of people or organizations you might want to reach out to with the hopes of making some type of agreement. Consider partners who can help improve efficiency or introduce innovative ways to streamline your business model. 
Share the Partnership Activity from the drive. 
Entrepreneurs should work individually 

5 minutes: Share and recap
Ask them to share and then wrap up with final thoughts including:
Find a partner that can bring skills and experience to the business. 
Find a partner that shares your values, entrepreneurial spirit, and vision.
Look for a partner without a lot of personal baggage.
Find a partner that can offer resources and credibility to your business.
Choose a partner that is financially stable.

17

Optimization and economies scale.
Reduction of risk.
Acquisition of needed resources.



PARTNERSHIP GOALS
3-5 minutes: Lecture

Optimization and economy of scale: The most basic form of partnership or buyer-supplier relationship is designed to optimize the allocation of resources and activities. It is illogical for a company to own all resources or perform every activity by itself. Optimization and economy of scale partnerships are usually formed to reduce costs, and often involve outsourcing or sharing infrastructure.
Reduction of risk and uncertainty: Partnerships can help reduce risk in a competitive environment characterized by uncertainty. It is not unusual for competitors to form a strategic alliance in one area while competing in another. Blu-ray, for example, is an optical disc format jointly developed by a group of the world’s leading consumer electronics, personal computer, and media manufacturers. The group cooperated to bring Blu-ray technology to market, yet individual members compete in selling their own Blu-ray products.
Acquisition of particular resources and activities: Few companies own all the resources or perform all the activities described by their business models. Rather, they extend their own capabilities by relying on other firms to furnish particular resources or perform certain activities. Such partnerships can be motivated by needs to acquire knowledge, licenses, or access to customers. A mobile phone manufacturer, for example, may license an operating system for its handsets rather than developing one in-house. An insurer may choose to rely on independent brokers to sell its policies rather than develop its own sales force.

18

Complete the tool to help you identify and fill your business gaps. 

Identify possible key partners to help fill gaps.
BUILD YOUR BUSINESS
5 minutes: Wrap up
19


THANK YOU
ANY QUESTIONS?
20

Looking at your "Identifying Organizational Gaps" module and the framework materials, I see several opportunities to integrate sustainability concepts naturally while maintaining the core business focus. Here's my assessment and recommendations:

## Current Status Assessment

Your current module focuses on:
1. Identifying business activity gaps
2. Determining what founders can handle themselves 
3. Exploring partnership options (joint ventures, strategic alliances, etc.)

The content is solid from a general business perspective but lacks integration of sustainability considerations that could enhance business resilience, efficiency, and market differentiation.

## Recommended Improvements

I suggest these targeted enhancements to subtly integrate sustainability without overwhelming the primary content:

### 1. For the Key Activities Brainstorm (Slide 5)

When listing potential business activities, add green considerations like:
- Resource/energy management
- Waste reduction/management
- Environmental compliance
- Sustainable sourcing

This frames sustainability as a standard business function rather than an add-on.

### 2. For the McKinsey 7S Model Discussion

Add sustainability-related prompts to the existing elements:
- **Systems**: Include efficient resource management systems and waste reduction processes
- **Skills**: Add expertise in resource optimization or environmental compliance 
- **Style**: Include how leadership approaches business resilience and long-term planning

### 3. For the "What Can I Do Myself?" Section

Add examples that highlight the efficiency-sustainability connection:
- "I can manage basic resource efficiency but need expertise for advanced optimization"
- "I understand compliance requirements but need help implementing systems"

### 4. For the Partnership Types Section

For each partnership type, add a sustainability-related example:

- **Joint Venture**: "Two companies partner to develop a more resource-efficient production process that neither could afford individually"
- **Strategic Alliance**: Add an example like "A food producer partners with a packaging company to develop more sustainable packaging solutions"
- **Buyer-Supplier**: Include "A company forms a partnership with suppliers who follow sustainable practices to ensure supply chain stability and meet customer values"

### 5. For the "Partnership Goals" Section

Add efficiency examples that connect business and environmental benefits:
- "Partners may collaborate to reduce packaging waste, benefiting both from reduced material costs"
- "Partnerships can help mitigate resource scarcity risks through shared innovation"

### 6. For the Partnership Planning Activity

Add to the handout instructions: "Consider partners who could help you identify resource efficiency opportunities or navigate changing environmental regulations affecting your industry."

These adjustments align with your framework's "Business-First Approach" by framing sustainability as a strategic advantage with concrete benefits rather than an ethical add-on.

Would you like me to provide specific slide-by-slide edits or focus on any particular section of this module?

The seven areas of organization are divided into the 'soft' and 'hard' areas. Strategy, structure and systems are hard elements that are much easier to identify and manage when compared to soft elements. On the other hand, soft areas, although harder to manage, are the foundation of the organization and are more likely to create the sustained competitive advantage.
Strategy is a plan developed by a firm to achieve sustained competitive advantage and successfully compete in the market. Someone needs to be focusing on creating a well-aligned strategy that is clearly articulated, long-term, and helps to achieve competitive advantage.
Structure represents the way business divisions and units are organized and includes the information of who is accountable to whom. Someone needs to organize the company in terms of management and organizational structure and tasks.

Skills are the abilities that firm's employees perform very well. They also include capabilities and competences. During organizational change, the question often arises of what skills the company will really need to reinforce its new strategy or new structure. Each business will need specific skills. Staff element is concerned with what type and how many employees an organization will need and how they will be recruited, trained, motivated and rewarded. Someone needs to train and onboard staff!

## Slide: PARTNERSHIP GOALS

**Current Facilitator Notes:**
```
Optimization and economy of scale: The most basic form of partnership or buyer-supplier relationship is designed to optimize the allocation of resources and activities. It is illogical for a company to own all resources or perform every activity by itself. Optimization and economy of scale partnerships are usually formed to reduce costs, and often involve outsourcing or sharing infrastructure.

Reduction of risk and uncertainty: Partnerships can help reduce risk in a competitive environment characterized by uncertainty. It is not unusual for competitors to form a strategic alliance in one area while competing in another. Blu-ray, for example, is an optical disc format jointly developed by a group of the world's leading consumer electronics, personal computer, and media manufacturers. The group cooperated to bring Blu-ray technology to market, yet individual members compete in selling their own Blu-ray products.

Acquisition of particular resources and activities: Few companies own all the resources or perform all the activities described by their business models. Rather, they extend their own capabilities by relying on other firms to furnish particular resources or perform certain activities. Such partnerships can be motivated by needs to acquire knowledge, licenses, or access to customers. A mobile phone manufacturer, for example, may license an operating system for its handsets rather than developing one in-house. An insurer may choose to rely on independent brokers to sell its policies rather than develop its own sales force.
```

**Updated Facilitator Notes:**
```

It is illogical for a company to own all resources or perform every activity by itself. Optimization and economy of scale partnerships are usually formed to reduce costs, and often involve outsourcing or sharing infrastructure. These partnerships can help businesses minimize waste, operate more efficiently, and reduce their resource use while improving profitability.

Reduction of risk and uncertainty: Partnerships can help reduce risk in a competitive environment characterized by uncertainty. This includes mitigating risks related to resource availability, price volatility, and changing market demands. For example, businesses may form partnerships to develop more efficient technologies that reduce their exposure to rising energy or water costs. Blu-ray is an example where competitors formed a strategic alliance in one area while competing in another - the group cooperated to bring Blu-ray technology to market, yet individual members compete in selling their own Blu-ray products.

Acquisition of particular resources and activities: Few companies own all the resources or perform all the activities described by their business models. Rather, they extend their own capabilities by relying on other firms to furnish particular resources or perform certain activities. Such partnerships can be motivated by needs to acquire knowledge, licenses, or access to customers. This might include partnering with specialists who have expertise in resource-efficient operations, water conservation techniques, or waste reduction processes. A manufacturer might partner with a waste management company to implement a system that turns production scraps into new resources, reducing costs while creating a new revenue stream.

Knowledge sharing and innovation: Partnerships can accelerate innovation by combining different perspectives and expertise. A local example might be a restaurant partnering with a packaging specialist to develop more efficient takeout containers that reduce costs while meeting customer expectations for durability.
```

```
5 minutes: Wrap up

Complete the tool to help you identify and fill your business gaps:
- Remember to consider both immediate operational needs and long-term business resilience
- Look for gaps in resource management expertise that might affect your costs and operations
- Consider how partnerships could help you identify efficiency opportunities that reduce expenses

When identifying possible key partners to help fill gaps:
- Consider partners with expertise in resource-efficient practices relevant to your industry
- Look for partners who can help you navigate changing regulations or market expectations
- Identify partners who share your commitment to business efficiency and long-term sustainability
- Think about how partners might help you access new markets or customers who value efficient, durable products

Remember that partnerships focused on efficiency and resource management often deliver multiple benefits: lower costs, reduced risk, and potential market differentiation.
```

These updates maintain the business-first focus while naturally integrating sustainability concepts as strategic business considerations rather than separate "green" add-ons. The changes connect environmental considerations directly to business benefits like cost savings, risk reduction, and market opportunities.

Not every Spotify consumer uses Uber, nor does every Uber rider has a Spotify account. The strategic alliance allows each company to pursue prospects from the other's existing customer base, all while continuing to promote both products.

Resource-sharing example: A business with excess warehouse space partners with a complementary business needing storage, reducing costs for both while optimizing resource use.

Efficiency partnership: A restaurant partners with a local farm to secure reliable produce while reducing transportation costs and ensuring freshness. The farm gains a steady customer while the restaurant can market its locally-sourced ingredients.

Technology-sharing example: A clothing manufacturer partners with a tech company that has developed water-efficient dyeing technology. The clothing company reduces production costs through water savings, while the tech company gets to scale its innovation.

You can partner with a manufacturer to produce a part of your business product that you yourself may not be able to manufacture. This can include suppliers with expertise in resource-efficient materials or processes that help reduce your costs.

## Slide: PARTNERSHIP GOALS

**Current Facilitator Notes:**
```
Optimization and economy of scale: The most basic form of partnership or buyer-supplier relationship is designed to optimize the allocation of resources and activities. It is illogical for a company to own all resources or perform every activity by itself. Optimization and economy of scale partnerships are usually formed to reduce costs, and often involve outsourcing or sharing infrastructure.

Reduction of risk and uncertainty: Partnerships can help reduce risk in a competitive environment characterized by uncertainty. It is not unusual for competitors to form a strategic alliance in one area while competing in another. Blu-ray, for example, is an optical disc format jointly developed by a group of the world's leading consumer electronics, personal computer, and media manufacturers. The group cooperated to bring Blu-ray technology to market, yet individual members compete in selling their own Blu-ray products.

Acquisition of particular resources and activities: Few companies own all the resources or perform all the activities described by their business models. Rather, they extend their own capabilities by relying on other firms to furnish particular resources or perform certain activities. Such partnerships can be motivated by needs to acquire knowledge, licenses, or access to customers. A mobile phone manufacturer, for example, may license an operating system for its handsets rather than developing one in-house. An insurer may choose to rely on independent brokers to sell its policies rather than develop its own sales force.
```
